awd_titl_txt: CDS&E: AAG: "glupyter": Enabling multi-dimensional linked data visualization with glue in the browser
awd_abstract_narration:
The open-source glue package allows scientists to explore relationships within and across related datasets.  It makes it easy to create multi-dimensional linked visualizations, to select subsets interactively or programmatically, and then see those selections in context.  A unique feature of glue is that it allows user-defined mathematical relationships between sets of data components.  Because of limitations with the current glue application, a new interface to glue is under development, called "glupyter".  The present award will support transforming glupyter from a proof-of-concept application to a fully featured, polished and science-grade application for astronomical research and beyond.  Glue and glupyter can be used across many fields of science, from exploring astronomical observations to analyzing radiological images of the brain to exploring patterns in multi-wavelength satellite images.  As their capabilities expand, so will their potential for impact outside of scientific research. They are already good tools for teaching the fundamentals of data exploration, and will enable new data-science curricula for students in grades 6-14. 

Cognitive and visualization research has long shown that humans are especially adept at seeing change, which is why real-time data exploration using linked views of high-dimensional data offers such an effective way to look for trends, outliers and salient subsets, even in very large data sets.  Commercial linked-view tools can be used for single tabular data files, but no extant tool handles linked-view selection in two-dimensional images and three-dimensional volumes spread across multiple files.  This is where the strength of glue lies.  Meanwhile, Jupyter notebooks are increasingly popular for data analysis, as they store an entire workflow using narrative text, code, and visualizations.  They encourage reproducibility and facilitate sharing.  Bringing glue into the Jupyter ecosystem as glupyter offers unparalleled potential for insight.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: PRESIDENT AND FELLOWS OF HARVARD COLLEGE

por.por_cntn:
Note: Images attached to this report should be viewed at their original aspect ratio, and they are all available at tinyurl.com/NSF-glupyter-images-24. 

glupyter": Enabling multi-dimensional linked data visualization with glue in the browser”

The open-source glue  package allows scientists to explore relationships within and across related datasets, by making it easy for them to make multi-dimensional linked visualizations of datasets, select subsets of data interactively or programmatically in 1, 2, or 3 dimensions, and see those selections propagate live across all open visualizations of the data (e.g. graphs, maps, diagnostics charts). A unique feature of glue is that datasets from different sources can be linked to each other, using user-defined mathematical relationships between sets of data components, which makes it possible to carry out selections across datasets.

Up until this award from NSF, researchers and learners could only effectively use glue as a  desktop application.  glue was and is open-source and free—but installation onto a desktop OS was required.  Today, though, thanks in large part to this NSF award, the “glue” code base  has been significantly expanded to allow the real-world use of “glupyter,” a version of glue that runs in the browser.  The current widespread applicability and use of glue and glupyter across astronomy, biology, and GIS have now inspired the visualization communities adjacent to those fields to join forces, with the Jupyter organization itself, to create the brand-new “Linkable, Interactive, Visualization, and Exploration”  or “LIVE” Environments project (LIVE-env.org).  Interest across science and education in building out and using LIVE is founded upon the many scientific discoveries and educational innovations glue and glupyter—and this grant—have enabled. Several of the most dramatic discoveries (e.g. in Astronomy, the existence of the Radcliffe Wave, the location of star-formation regions on the surface of the Local Bubble)  were complete surprises— only made possible by the linked-view high-dimensional visualization tools glue and glupyter offer. 

The LIVE Environments projecct, established in early 2024, is the direct descendant of this NSF award, and the community-wide effort and support its foundation represents is the glue/glupyter team’s greatest accomplishment.

Intellectual Merit:

Having selections propagate between multiple views of a dataset is referred to as "brushing and linking” or "linked-views." While this paradigm has been used well outside of science, it is surprisingly under-used by astronomers and scientists in general. Commercial linked-view tools can be brought to bear on scientific data when it is all within one data file, in tabular form. But, when investigations rely on high-dimensional images (e.g. in astronomy or medicine), no extant tool can be used as none handles linked-view selection in 2D images and 3D volumes. Furthermore, scientists' data are often spread across multiple files, and being able to visualize and interact with multiple datasets simultaneously is crucial for exploratory data analysis. Cognitive and visualization research has long shown that humans are especially adept at seeing change, which is why real-time data exploration using linked views of high-dimensional data offers such an effective way to look for trends, outliers and salient subsets, even in very large data sets. At the start of this grant, glue was the only software package allowing for real-time exploration of high- dimensional data spread across multiple files.  

Over the period of the grant, as new software functionality was added, tested, and deployed, it was prottyped using astronomical, genomics, and GIS investigations undertaken by teams sharing members with those developing the new glue and glupyter features.  As a result, not only did the team build out glupyter to the point where it is now the foundation of LIVE Environments, they also participated in several scientific papers presenting completely new knowledge about our Universe.

Broader Impacts:

While this award supported foundational improvements to the core glupyter codebase, its range of impact was unusually broad, in part because NSF’s infrastructure funding was highly leveraged with complementary support from other government agencies and private institutions.  Leveraged by NASA funding, glupyter is now the underlying code base of JDaviz, the data visualization package provided with data from the James Webb Space Telescope.  Leveraged by NASA and private funders, glupyter is used in concert with WorldWide Telescope (also supported by NSF) to teach data science using astronomiy and Earth science examples under the “Cosmic Data Stories” program based at Harvard.  Leveraged by a 2022 NSF grant to develop augmented reality (AR) tools for astronomers, glupyter has recently been used to create AR figures viewable directly in a browser.  Supported by funds from Google, Harvard, and this award, glupyter underlies new GIS tools built for use by climate change mitigation researchers and activists as part of the Climate+Data effort at Harvard.  And, glue genes (for genomics) was built on glue with private support from the Jackson Laboratory, and feeds directly into the  LIVE project, which will continue to expand glue and glupyter’s reach. 


Last Modified: 03/13/2024
Modified by: Alyssa A Goodman

The LIVE Environments projecct, established in early 2024, is the direct descendant of this NSF award, and the community-wide effort and support its foundation represents is the glue/glupyter teams greatest accomplishment.

While this award supported foundational improvements to the core glupyter codebase, its range of impact was unusually broad, in part because NSFs infrastructure funding was highly leveraged with complementary support from other government agencies and private institutions. Leveraged by NASA funding, glupyter is now the underlying code base of JDaviz, the data visualization package provided with data from the James Webb Space Telescope.
